utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: The trick to onions — cut them in half length-wise, but leave the roots on. Then make your vertical slices. Need a dozen. Think you can handle this?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: A dozen is 12, right?

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: Next, we add mustard greens — spicy, and they pack a nice punch. Plus, they're really good for you. Improve mental function, protect against rheumatoid arthritis. Even inhibit certain types of cancer. Are you going to chop those onions or give them a Thai massage?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Well, I guess a happy ending is out of the question.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: I don't recall adding making snide remarks to your list of duties.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Just taking initiative.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: Secret ingredient: Porcini mushrooms. You want to reconstitute them in bowl of water.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Just give me a second.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: You're kidding me, right?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: So sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: Are you okay? You want to sit down?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: My lips are blue. Cyanosis. Pain in my back and chest. Spontaneous pneumothorax.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I'm a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Chef Anthony
utterance.content: You are?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: And I need a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You drool.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Shut up.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I know gas is expensive, but I could've given you a ride.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Elevator's broken.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It was fine when I came up from admitting.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Dana Miller, the cancer researcher. Spontaneous pneumothorax.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Awfully thin file.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She just got admitted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lots of things can cause pneumothorax. Why don't we let eight or ten other doctors rule out the boring stuff?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We wanna take this case. She's maybe five or ten years away from curing retinoblastoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which would make this case attractive to anyone who has some vested interest in people curing the incurable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She hasn't suffered from COPD. She doesn't smoke. She hasn't been scuba diving. O2 sats are low even after chest tube insertion.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Pneumothorax could be secondary to a bunch of things. Cystic fibrosis, lung cancer.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Or, to be slightly more optimistic, late-onset asthma triggered by an unknown allergen.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We have a case?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you just get to work?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Am I in trouble?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you take the elevators up?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: So, steroids for asthma?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Do a CT looking for hyperinflation to confirm.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I thought my hospital was high-tech. I'd have to wait all day for a CT.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Dr. House gets a few perks.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: He has his own scanner?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No, just very loose interpretations of hospital procedure.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I appreciate the extra effort, but —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Our gift to society. We want to get you back to work as soon as possible.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Well, I'm not working. At least not as a doctor I quit. I left eight months ago.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You mean, like, a sabbatical?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I had a uterine myoma. Benign. But it ruptured and I needed emergency surgery. I was lying there on the table thinking, "I can't die now. I haven't been happy yet."

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Couldn't you just buy an overpriced German sports car, or have an affair?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: My sports car is doing what I want when I want. Right now I'm learning how to run a kitchen from one of the best chefs in New York.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're washing pots and smashing garlic?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Smashing garlic makes me happy. Before that it was eight years studying, 12 years in that lab. It was always what I was supposed to do, and never what I wanted to do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Come here. Look at this. Come here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Adorable. Elevators keep crashing. Is Mercury in retrograde or what?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Elevators can be capricious. Sometimes it just seems like they're out to get you. She keeps playing with the blanket. Why would she do that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you think the elevators would be out to get me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't know. Maybe they wanted to take time off to spend with their little dumbwaiter. But then they had to leave it at home with an elevator sitter, because you drove the replacement elevator to quitting because, you're incapable of listening to anybody but me. That's just a theory.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're wrong. I don't even listen to you. Either do your job or go home. Leave me out of it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am gonna do my job. It doesn't mean I have to do it happily. Doesn't mean I have to do it without resentment. And it definitely doesn't mean I have to do it without seeking vengeance on the person making me be here. Congratulations. You've officially dragged me down to your level.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, Blue.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It’s not asthma. Lung volume is normal. She did have a uterine myoma removed eight months ago. Central line IV could have made a hole near the lung that slowly expanded.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No pleural thickening. I can't believe she quit.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: People have the right to be happy.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I saw a four-year-old with retinoblastoma on my oncology rotation. The cancer had eaten through her eye and into her brain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Horrible diseases exist. It doesn't mean people should give up recreational anything.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why not? Big picture — I don't care if Jonas Salk’s life is a miserable shell. I just want him to cure polio.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You can't live your life "big picture." You've gotta look out for yourself and the people you care about.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Well, then, why are you a doctor? Why aren't you sitting by a pool in Fiji knocking back mai tais?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People act in their own self-interests. You're all here because you're happy to be here. Or at least because it's your best option.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I'm here because I want to help people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you're here because it makes you feel good to help people. Taub and Foreman are here because they've got no other viable choices. And Thirteen is desperate to make her life matter before it's over.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So... you're happy to be here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does it show?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Are those... increased interstitial markings?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be pulmonary fibrosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do a biopsy. Foreman. "You've got to look out for the people you care about." That wouldn't have anything to do with you screwing over your clinical trial by slipping Thirteen the real drug would it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You said that would be stupid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does she know? Because Jonas Salk would not approve.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's nothing to know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got it? Good?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yep.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Just a headache. I took some ibuprofen, but —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where's the pain, front or back?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Front. Why are there never any interesting pictures on these cards? They should make a dirty version.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A sharp pain, or more of a throbbing —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Relax, it's not a side effect. People get headaches.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: True, but I can get you an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If I'm on the drug, it's been weeks. It's not like something's going to suddenly crop up now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay. First card.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Train, duck...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You can't remember?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Piano.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We need a biopsy to confirm —

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: You need an open-lung biopsy to confirm pulmonary fibrosis. That's invasive surgery. I'd be out of commission for weeks.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No offense, but you're not working. What does it matter if you spend a little time in bed?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Not working doesn't mean I don't have places to go. I've got my book group, piano lessons, cooking classes. They make me happy.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: A warm apple fritter makes me happy. It doesn't fulfill me as a person.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: And working here does?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If it didn't, I’d have found a way to go back to tucking tummies.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Well, good for you. If your job fulfills you and makes you happy, that's rare.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I didn't say I was happy. I loved being a plastic surgeon. The money, the life style, and in a lot of ways this job stinks. I'm making five bucks, I’m always annoyed... but —

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: You can look yourself in the mirror and think, "I did something worthwhile today."

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Exactly.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: That's important. And I do miss that. But it just wasn't enough anymore. That doesn't feel right.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Sit up.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Oh, that's weird. What is it? Ascites?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Ow!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Your belly's full of blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First her lung deflates, like me after a cold shower. Now her liver starts to bleed, like me after—

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great. Just practicing my clown college audition.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Someone set a trip wire. We were with the patient the whole time.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We were in the GRC.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lung, liver, go.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Shouldn't you be obsessing over who did this to you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope — anybody bother MRIing our patient's liver for tumors?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, no tumors, no cysts, no clear etiology.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If you're not obsessing, you must have already figured it out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. So I'm obsessing about why you're not obsessing about why our patient's liver suddenly sprang a leak.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's a tiny spot on the caudate lobe. Could be a granuloma. Erodes into the hepatic artery, causes the bleed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What caused the granuloma?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Blastomycosis. Could have been asymptomatic for months. It hits her lungs, we give her steroids. It blossoms and attacks her liver.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get a piece of her lung, stick it under a black light. If it glows, sick children who need her soufflés can breathe easier.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Again?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I told you, I didn't —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you really have a problem. The way she turned her head to look at the MRI... I think she's losing her peripheral vision.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Because she turned her head?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm happy for you. A love so deep you're ready to chuck your medical license to give her powerful, unproven drugs with dangerous side effects. I don't want to make any assumptions about your feelings for me, but I do have a birthday coming up.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I hear Cuddy's SEAL training finally came in handy. Should I be investing in a flak jacket?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're safe.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No carpet bombing? No burning of Dresden to teach her a lesson? Well, since you're incapable of taking the high road, I assume there's some deeper, more long-term strategy in effect.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy's not playing games. She's not looking for leverage. She wants pure, unadulterated vengeance.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And your counter-move is to let her have it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The only time to strike back is when I want something. All I want now is to get things back to normal. Which I can't get by escalating. The only way to win this war is to lose it. Let her punch herself out.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, that makes sense too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: "Too"?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I was thinking you actually feel guilty about taking her away from her baby. But your explanation's good too. It's completely inconsistent with your character, but whatever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, thank you, rationalization man. You have saved the village. You wanna eat?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You forgot your file. Dana Miller? The cancer researcher?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not anymore.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dr. Miller, I doubt if you'll remember me —

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: James Wilson, right? Chicago, the adenocarcinoma conference.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Impressive. You want some cortisone for that itch?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Liver failure. Itching is one of the lovely side effects.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why did you quit?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Well, the worst thing is now every time I get sick, I have to listen to a dozen people judge me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you want me to congratulate you? I've got four kids in pede-onc right now who are gonna die. Three of them within a year, the other in a few days, probably.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Breakthroughs will happen. With or without me, someone will find the answer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe. I — I... I'm in the trenches. I'm — I'm doing triage as best I can. You had the chance to end the war. How is someone like me supposed to keep fighting when someone like you just... walked away?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: When I left my job, a lot of people were furious with me. It was easier to be angry than to admit they weren't happy. That they were stuck in a rut somewhere in their lives, unable to move forward. What's your rut?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Okay, you're freaking me out.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Do you think we should have kids?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: We've had this conversation.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Ten years ago. Things change.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: On our third date I told you that I didn't want to have kids, and you said that you were okay with that.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I said it because I wanted to sleep with you. And then I fell in love with you. And I realized that I really could be okay with it. It wasn't like I had this burning desire to have children.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: God, have you been resenting me all this time? Is that why —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. Of course not. I'm just... revisiting.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: This isn't a whim for me. It's not a decision that I made lightly.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Don't you ever wonder what it would be like?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: All the time. Just not enough to make me want to do it. I like our life. Are you okay? Can I turn the TV back on?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look straight ahead.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why didn't we do this test this morning?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You see that?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Damn.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I'm losing my peripheral vision? I am on the drug. Does this mean you have to tell them and take me off it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, and yes. As far as they're concerned, you're on the placebo. I found out last week. The trial was getting positive results... So I switched you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: So my headaches... I'll stop taking the drug, and everything should be fine.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Specimen's negative for blastomycosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's it?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I'll go give House the test results. You can tell the patient.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We've been dating for two weeks. You just broke trial protocol and risked your entire career to give me a drug we're not even sure will help me. I don't think I'm ready for that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Miller? I'm sorry. The test was negative. So I'm gonna take you off — what happened to your head?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I don't know. I was sleeping. It's so itchy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were scratching it in your sleep. You scratched right through your skull. This is brain matter. Need some help in here!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I did a free flap closure to avoid any scarring. She was lucky — the scratching didn't cause any brain damage. But the first thing she said when we woke her up was, “It still itches.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Itch receptors are only in the top two layers of skin. Which means she's not actually itchy, she just thinks she is.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So the problem's in her brain?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Thank God we have you here to interpret that for us. Sorry, I have a headache.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Could be psychogenic. She made a big, sudden change in her life. Could be the result of a mental imbalance.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She wants to do what she wants to do. What's crazy about that?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Why do you have to quit to do it? If I want to do something, I do it. If you can figure out a balance, there's no burnout.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks for the lesson, Deepak. The itching started yesterday, not eight months ago. Meningitis, encephalitis...

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Those are diffuse processes. This is localized.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be plaques. MS would explain, possibly the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So would a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, how 'bout we stop guessing and MRI her head instead?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You want to talk about your headaches?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not particularly.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You went off the drug, but the headaches are worse. You need an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The patient needs an MRI. If she had gangrene, would you be amputating my leg?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Those pills have codeine in them? You're taking twice the indicated amount.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I've only been off the drug for 24 hours, so I think the bigger issue here is that I've been off you for 24 hours.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You have worsening headaches, loss of peripheral vision, and a long history of pretending bad things aren't happening. You really think this is just about my hurt feelings?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't remember demoting you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I brought you something. The latest issue of “Parent” magazine. Really interesting column. Apparently, working moms are actually more engaged and attentive than stay-at-home moms. Something about personal fulfillment.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's just a rationalization by working moms to justify not being with their kids. Which is fine, if that's what they want. It's not what I want. And this is “Nurses Quarterly.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The point is —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're only here to get back at me by dumping dirty mop water on my carpet. Just get it over with so I can get back to work.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm sorry. I figured... only one of us needed to go out on a limb. I thought I could help you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It's hard to have a conversation when I'm trying not to move.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Patient's MRI was negative. No tumors, no lesions.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Where's your cane?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where are your coworkers?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I paged them.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It could still be psychogenic.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Technically, it can't still be that, because it never could be that. She scratched through her skull while she was sleeping. Unless she was having a dream about fleas —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, hey, funny you should drop by. We were just talking about this patient of ours. Tell him the part about where two of her doctors don't show up — Where are you going? Polyneuropathy. It's not in the brain, it's in the nerves. It explains the itching, the lungs, the liver. Shock the affected area, reboot the nerve — she'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman. How bad is she?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's got a tumor in her optic chiasm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't need your coat to treat a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm going to the drug company.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To tell them that you compromised their trial, your ethics, and the patient's health? That's a great idea.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They have records on hundreds of patients. I can ask them for access, find out if other patients developed tumors and how they were treated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This drug inhibits cell death. I think I could take a wild guess at how I treat that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stop taking it? Yeah. She tried that yesterday.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, my God, it's been a whole day, and her brain tumor hasn't melted away? If you get on that elevator, and it's only 'cause you're worried about getting to sleep tonight —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I want to be able to tell her this happened to other people, and they're fine now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So tell her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm not gonna lie to her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A little late for that. You need to wait. Because if this thing doesn't go away, she's gonna need you to still have a medical license.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So I spoke with House. He thinks we should just —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: My leg is bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I was going for the phone, and I fell over the table. I can't see.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I can't see anything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You gonna tip housekeeping?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get it from Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don't tell me — she burned your apartment to the ground.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Warmth would have been nice. No heat, no power. Apparently Mrs. House called the utilities and told them we were moving.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have 17 messages. And your non-involvement strategy doesn't seem to be working.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hang up, he's here.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We've been paging you all night.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: By all means, let's discuss the failed attempts to contact me, not the reason behind them.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Patient started experiencing spinal shocks before the machine was turned on. L’Hermitte's sign.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shocks without shock, an itch that won't stop. She needs Dr. Seuss.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: L’Hermitte's sign could mean Behcet's, B-12 deficiency.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No sores, no anemia. Where's Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No idea.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Could be another demyelinating disease. Why are you asking about Foreman and not Thirteen?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because both questions are bound to have the same answer. Ebony and ivory are joined near the hip. Forget the brain. Look lower.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The spinal tumor wouldn't explain the liver or the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But an aggressive spinal hemangioma could.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go find it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn't answer the door.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Probably because I didn't want to talk to anyone. You can leave your stolen key on your way out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was looking for Foreman. I figured... You can't see. Where is he?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: On his way to the drug company.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell him to come back. I'll dial.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If they can help.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think that drug company has a magic tumor wand that no one else knows about? You need radiation, not ritual sacrifice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He asked for my advice before he switched you off the placebo. I told him to do it if he loved you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He only thinks he loves me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's the same thing. Yes, he's an idiot. You didn't ask him to do anything. You're pissed off that he did. So let him torch his career to pay for his sins. Unless, you actually feel something for the idiot. In which case, you might want to tell him to turn around.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're hurting him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good, after all the stunts he's pulled on me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're physically hurting him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's the point.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What's the point? What do you think you're going to accomplish?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House shouldn't be allowed to make people miserable without paying for it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're not miserable!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're telling me how I feel?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're here because you like this. You like working with him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wow, if only I'd known I was having fun, I wouldn't have canceled the bouncy house.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fire him, and go be home with your new baby.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I like what he does for this hospital.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What he does is who he is. And the same goes for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Slow down. Unless you want to radiate her heart instead of her brain. Of course, then your problems would actually all go away.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thanks. I'm not beating myself up enough already over this. Entering the left common carotid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You broke the rules. Girlfriend went blind. You gotta be ready for losing to be one of the possibilities. You're at the carotid bifurcation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I knew that giving her the drug would be bad for me if I got caught. I never thought it would be bad for her. Nobody else was having adverse reactions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You did it because you love her. Ironically, you never took her into consideration. Can't wait to see what you get her for your anniversary. Catheter's adjacent to the optic chiasm. We're in position. Nukey, nukey.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: What's going on with everyone today?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It involves House, Foreman, and Thirteen, which means it's either dumb, dangerous, or tragic, or a combination. I'm embracing my ignorance.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: House was right about the hemangioma. Looks fixable.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What's that? Hemangiomas travel solo. This thing has brought a friend. Masses in her lungs and spine. One in her pericardium.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: They're everywhere.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Classic mesothelioma. It metastasized outward to the spine and muscles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ah, the irony of it. Maybe she wouldn't be sick at all if some other lazy cancer researcher hadn't gone home early.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Where are Foreman and Thirteen?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shouldn't you be saying, "Those weren't there when we scanned her two days ago?”

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Mesothelioma shouldn't grow this fast.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good rephrasing. Have Wilson do a biopsy to confirm.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No. Something weird is going on. It involves our colleagues — we should know. You want us to treat the patient, tell us what's going on.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Actually, all he needs us to do is tell Wilson to do something. So...

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You always blab to watch people react. So not blabbing means you don't want us to react, which can't be good. Is Thirteen's headache not just a headache? If I check with Admitting, am I gonna find her name?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: A little pinch. I'm sorry about the other day. I... unloaded on you. And...

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: You're not sorry. You feel bad because mesothelioma means I'm dying. You're a good person. I appreciate the sentiment.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm not apologizing because you're dying. I'm apologizing because you were right. I am stuck. My girlfriend died. She was the only person I've loved for a long time, and... I'm still living in her apartment. I'm surrounded by her things. I have left it all exactly where it was. I don't know how to get unstuck.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: The only wrong thing is... to do nothing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. All right.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: That's not supposed to happen.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Have you thought about going to the drug company, see if they can help?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I thought about it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We need to give it more time. It's been half a day.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This thing keeps growing, there's other stuff in your brain you might need later on.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If I were any other patient, you'd both be in the lounge, eating donuts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're not any other patient.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Right. Any other patient, you don't feel guilty. But you don't get to torch your career to pay for your sins.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House told you to say that, didn't he?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Does that make it any less true?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think he's right?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Who cares? You're a hypocrite. You don't ask her if she wants to be on the drug, but when there's a chance you could help her get better, suddenly you're letting her call the shots? That's not being noble. That's saving your own ass.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I'd feel worse if he destroyed his career.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mesothelioma doesn't bleed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what causes masses that do bleed?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: AVM's secondary to schistosomiasis.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She'd be crawling with worms. We'd have noticed it. Gorham's disease and Kasabach-Merritt can both cause super-aggressive vascular tumors. Patient's heart just stopped.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what causes that?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cardiac tamponade. She's bleeding into her pericardium, smothering her heart. Syringe.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: BP’s going back up. It's working.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No, it's not — look.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We're transfusing platelets, FFP, everything to try to keep her stable. But we can barely keep up with the blood loss. At this rate, she could be dead by the end of the day.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We need to resect the vascular tumors, stop the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too late — no surgeon's gonna touch her now.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So we give up? Just let her bleed out?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't be silly. You know what that would do to our malpractice insurance rates? We go on the offensive. Cut off the invading army's supply line.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're talking about embolization?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cut off the arteries that feed blood to the tumors, they wither and die. Start with the ones in her lungs. If they get any bigger, she's gonna have a hard time breathing. So she'll have a hard time telling us she's dead.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You can't kill the tumors without also killing healthy tissue. If we wipe out 3/4 of her lungs...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let's hope that running marathons wasn't on her happy list.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I found this. In the, uh, coat closet. Where I hid it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thought I'd never see you again. Little, little Greg. Yeah, you heard me right!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You are who you are. It's annoying, but... it's not your fault. It isn't about you. I… I… I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because you were doing this job perfectly until the baby came along.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What? I'm apologizing. Can't you just accept my —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I accept. We gonna have to do this dance again in 28 days?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What the hell is wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yesterday, you hate me. Today, you're practically weeping on my shoulder. I can only assume that what I'm hearing is your aunt flow telling me...

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: When I was being a jerk, you suddenly act human. But when I act human, you turn back into a jerk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guess our cycles aren't matched up yet.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is your way of saying you accept my apology, isn't it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, this is my way of saying you were doing a crappy job before; you will do a slightly crappier job now. Everything keeps going. Nature of life. Nature of parenthood.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Or this whole thing is just an act. And you've gone back to the part you think you need to play.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You should go talk to Wilson. Rationalization Man needs a faithful sidekick. Now, Rational Man needs to go save a life.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: House. If you're looking for returnable bottles, Kutner’s already cleaned it out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn! Oh, well. That means the only thing I'm gonna get out of this... Is a diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So the nurses gave her pads instead of tampons. Is that diagnostically relevant?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fact that the nurses had to give her anything is. Means she's bleeding from her uterus.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Women do that. It's perfectly natural. Not scary at all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She menstruating and, she's bleeding everywhere. There's about a 3 or 4 in 28 chance it's a coincidence. Which leaves a much bigger chance that the diagnosis is ectopic endometriosis. She had a myoma eight months ago. Surgeons cut through her uterine wall. Every cut of the scalpel could have sent endometrial cells spilling out into her bloodstream. Some of them took up residence in her lungs, some in her liver, some in her spine. And like all horny little cells, they went forth and multiplied till they reached a critical mass. In the days leading up to her next period, when her uterus is supposed to swell, everything swelled. And when her uterus was supposed to bleed, everything bled. Yes, ladies, I am blaming her period. Granted, it's the worst period ever. Although, frankly, not by all that much. Cut out the masses, she'll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Can't do surgery until her cycle's over and she stops bleeding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, let's hope she can hold out till then. In the meantime, get her a pint of cookie dough ice cream and a DVD of “Beaches”.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Foreman? I can see you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How you feeling?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: Relative to the last few days, awesome.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You almost died. For the second time in eight months.

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How do you feel about your life choices this time?

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: I didn't lie there thinking "what if?"

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I always worry, on my deathbed I'll think, "I didn't do anything really important."

utterance.speaker: Dana
utterance.content: You're gonna spend one day of your life on your deathbed. The other 25,000 are the ones we should be worrying about. Go to bed happy tonight.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Schmidt. It's Eric Foreman. Uh, actually, the trial isn't going too well.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You told them, didn't you? Well, you really had no choice... On account of being an idiot. They gonna pull the drug?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I broke protocol. Her results are no longer admissible to the trial. They don't have to do anything. Anyone else gets a tumor, they'll put a warning on the label.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gonna keep your license?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They'll come after me if I attempt to participate in any more trials.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's very decent of them. Well, good for me. I'll see you tomorrow. And the next day. And the next day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That wasn't your locker, was it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's a lock-er room. How else are they gonna learn?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Do you think you can't be happy without a kid?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don't know. I know I can't be happy without you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You snore.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Shut up.
